description: A piece of under-used property that has become a sinkhole for taxpayers has become an issue in Hempstead’s mayoral race.
title: Troubled Building Cited in Hempstead Mayoral Race
title_page: Troubled Building Cited in Hempstead Mayoral Race - The New York Times
maintext:
HEMPSTEAD
THE two-story building at 100 Main Street here occupies an entire block, houses dozens of shops and is strategically located steps away from a courthouse, a bus terminal and a railroad station.
But most of the interior is vacant. For more than a decade the property has been a financial sinkhole, costing taxpayers millions of dollars and diverting money from community programs, local officials say.
An audit this month found extensive mismanagement, and that report has stirred debate in the campaign for mayor in the March 18 village election.
“The village has been screaming about this for years,” said the Nassau County comptroller, Howard S. Weitzman, who issued the audit. He said the managers “ran this thing into the ground.”
